attributes.title: Meta-analysis on Secondary Transfer Effects of Intergroup Contact
attributes.description: We conduct a meta-analysis on the secondary transfer effect of intergroup contact. The secondary transfer effect refers to a situation when contact with one social group changes attitudes towards other social groups.

summary.value: We preregister a meta-analysis on the secondary transfer effect of intergroup contact using the Prisma-P checklist, which is a protocol for the preregistration of meta-analyses and systematic reviews. The codebook for this meta-analysis is attached as well.

registration_responses.summary: We preregister a meta-analysis on the secondary transfer effect of intergroup contact using the Prisma-P checklist, which is a protocol for the preregistration of meta-analyses and systematic reviews. The codebook for this meta-analysis is attached as well.

comments.value:
Data was collected between Sept 2016 & Dec 2016.
For the first part of this project - related to an impact case study on how Religious Education teachers use contact theory in their classroom - the data has been analyzed and published.
The second part of the project - related to diversity mindset and teachers' beliefs - has not yet been examined in that the data has not been processed in any way.

attributes.title: The validity of trait implicit self-esteem

q1.value: The validity of trait implcit self-esteem

q3.value: Many studies demonstrated the malleability of measures of implicit self-esteem (ISE). This supposed malleability, however, is in conflict with previous theories conceiving ISE as a highly overlearned and stable self-association that is formed in early interpersonal interactions. The main question of this study is, whether there is a stable trait component of “implicit self-esteem” (TISE) which has incremental validity over and above the trait component of explicit self-esteem (TESE) in predicting plausible correlates of self-esteem.

q4.value:
TISE is positively correlated with TESE. (directional hypothesis)
High TISE is predicting low trait depression, low trait neuroticism, high trait satisfaction with life, and trait positive interpretation of ambiguous scenarios even when controlling for TESE.  (directional hypotheses)
TISE is predicting trait feedback-seeking behavior even when controlling for TESE.  (non-directional hypothesis)
Remembered parental bonding is predicting TISE even when controlling for TESE: High care predicts high TISE, high overprotection predicts low TISE. (directional hypotheses)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated measures / longitudinal design with 4 waves and an interval of 2 weeks. No between-subject manipulation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited online via the platform prolific. To minimize dropout, we will only recruit participants, who already took part in more than 10 studies and have an approval rate of greater than 95% on prolific. Participants will on average be paid 8,74$/hour when completing all sessions. Only participants who completed all preceding sessions will be invited to take part in the next session. The payment of a session is conditional on the completion of the next session.

Sessions will be unlocked for one whole week and participants will be reminded to take part. Participants, who do not the session during this time are considered dropouts.

q14.value: Since this study is closely related to a paper by Dentale et al. (2016) we aim to replicate their sample size.

question.value:
Measures of ISE (T1 to T4):
1. A modified self-esteem IAT paradigm (Meissner & Rothermund, 2013). From this task, indices of ISE will be calculated: 1. the raw IAT effect, 2. the D2 score, 3. the A1 parameter of the ReAL model (Meissner & Rothermund, 2013) which is applied to the error data of the IAT. Exploratively, we will also calculate association parameters based on the Quad model (Conrey, 2005) and use diffusion modeling (Klauer et al., 2007).

2. The Name-letter Task. An estimator of ISE will be computed by the I-algorithm (LeBel & Gawronski, 2009).

Measures of ESE:
1. The State Self-Esteem Scale. The sum of all items will be calculated as an indicator of state ESE. (T1 to T4)
The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale. The sum of items will be calculated as an indicator of trait ESE. (T1 and T4)

Antecedent variable:

1. Remembered parental bonding measured by the sum score of the two scales of the parental bonding instrument. (T3)

Criterion variables:

1. Life Satisfaction measured by the sum score of the "Satisfaction With Life Scale". (T1 and T4)
2. Neuroticism measured by the sum score of the Emotional Instability scale of the IPIP Big-Five Factor Markers. (T1 and T4)
3. Interpretation of ambiguous scenarios measured by the sum score of the Ambiguous Scenario Test. (T1 and T4)
4. Feedback Seeking measured by the sum score of the Feedback Seeking Questionnaire. (T1 and T4)
5. Depression measured by the sum score of Becks Depression Inventory II. (T1 and T4)

We will use SEM to fit a latent state-trait model (single trait, multiple states) to the multiple measurements of ISE, ESE and criterion variables. Manifest variables will be test-halves wherever possible. Otherwise, single items will be used. These models will be used to estimate the consistency, specificity, and reliability of measures. Equivalent dual-construct measures will be used to estimate TISE-TESE intercorrelations and predictive power of the remembered parental bonding. Triple-construct measures will be used to investigate the incremental validity of TISE over TESE in predicting the trait component of criterion variables.

q21.value: P-values of lower than .05 will be regarded as significant. Two-tailed tests will be used for non-directional hypotheses, single-tailed tests will be used for directional hypotheses.

q22.value: Submissions/Data from participants who failed our attention checks or answered randomly will be rejected. Subjects who do not complete all sessions will be excluded from the analysis.

q23.value: Subjects who do not complete all sessions will be excluded from the analysis. Other missing data is prevented by the fact, that all responses are required to continue in the experiment.

attributes.title: Attention contagion in a realistic classroom

q1.value: Attention contagion in a realistic classroom setting

q3.value:
-	In a previous study conducted by Forrin et al. (2020), it was demonstrated that attentiveness and inattentiveness can spread between a confederate and participant watching a lecture video.
-	The attentiveness/inattentiveness of a confederate directly affected the participants’ self-report of attentiveness as well as their subsequent performance on a multiple-choice test (Forrin et. al., 2020).
-	Although the spread of attention (attention contagion) has been observed between a single participant and a single confederate, we are interested to see if this would occur in a more realistic classroom setting containing a larger group of participants and confederates.
-	The study we will conduct is a follow up to the study conducted by Forrin et al. (2019) containing more participants and confederates, resembling a more ecologically valid classroom setting.
-	We will also examine whether the proximity to attentive/inattentive confederates affects the degree to which attentiveness spreads.
-	Additionally, we want to understand whether social appraisal theory drives attention contagion in the classroom.
-	Attentiveness affects how well a student is able to learn, therefore, it is important to understand the factors that affects attention.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that compared to the inattentive condition, participants in the attentive condition will (1) report being more attentive (2) perform better on the multiple-choice quiz (3) take more notes (4) be coded as being more attentive by video coders (5) report being more motivated while watching the lecture (6) rate the material as being more important and (7) more likely to respond “yes” to receiving more information about the topic (human vision) that was covered in the lecture. 

Additionally, we predict that the closer participants are to confederates, the more strongly they will be influenced by confederates’ behaviour (whether attentive or inattentive).  We also predict that the more visible confederates are to participants, the more strongly they will be influenced by confederates’ behaviour.  Beyond these broad “visibility” and “proximity” hypotheses, we do not have more specific hypotheses (for example, we will not be proposing a mathematical model of how attentiveness spreads in the classroom).  More specific postdictions will be tested with exploratory analyses (e.g., social networking analyses) after we consult with a social network analysis expert.

Further, we hypothesize that notetaking mediates the relation between experimental condition and multiple-choice quiz performance, and also that attentiveness ratings mediate the relation between experimental condition and multiple-choice quiz performance.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value:
The experimenter will be aware of the hypothesis and which of the two conditions is being run.  The confederates will be aware of each condition is being run (they have to be aware in order to know how to act during the lecture), but they won’t be aware of the hypothesis.  Following the study, the confederates will be asked what they thought that the hypothesis was and we will record how many of the 15 confederates correctly knew the hypothesis.
Video coders will be blind to the manipulation and to the hypothesis.

question.value:
This study will use a between-subject design containing two experimental conditions, and participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions. Each session will contain 45 participants and 15 confederates. In one condition, participants will watch the lecture video with confederates behaving attentively (look frequently at the lecture, take frequent notes, have a good (upright) posture) and in the other condition, participants will watch the lecture video with confederates behaving inattentively (look relatively infrequently at the lecture, take infrequent lecture notes, have poor (slouching) posture). 

The study will be taking place in the LIVE lab in the psychology building at McMaster University. The experiment will be video recorded covertly, and participants will be debriefed and told about both the presence of confederates and the video recording that took place. The lecture video will be a 30-minute lecture video on human colour vision, and participants will be given note paper to take notes on. Approximately ever 5 minutes, the video will stop for 10 seconds and participants will be asked to rate their attentiveness on a scale from 0 to 10. At the end of the video, participants will be presented with a multiple-choice quiz assessing their retention of the content, along with a post-lecture survey assessing how important they thought the lecture was, how motivated they were, and several manipulation checks (e.g., how attentive other participants were in the room).

q9.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to either experimental conditions based on the timeslot they choose to sign up for on SONA. Participants will be unaware of what condition they have signed up for.  Participants will be randomly assigned seats when they arrive.  
Confederates will be pre-assigned seats.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the McMaster SONA subject pool.  They will be Introductory Psychology students who will be reimbursed with course credit.

q13.value: There will be 90 students recruited per condition. Since there are two conditions, there will be a total of 180 students recruited for this study.

q14.value: We are collecting as many participants as we can given our resource limitations.  I.e., hiring 15 confederates, paying to use McMaster's LIVELab, getting large groups of 45 SONA participants.

q15.value: Four session of 45 participants each will be run.

question.value:
-	Attentiveness: Participants will be with confederates who will either act attentively or inattentively
-	The distance of participants from the confederates will be manipulated in each session, as will the visibility of confederates.  This will be done in several ways:  On one side of the room (counterbalanced across session), there will be 15 participants who are not sitting amongst participants.  Some rows will have confederates and others will not.

1)	Self reported attentiveness will be measured (on a scale from 0-10) through periodic probes that will be displayed during the lecture video
2) Self-reported attentiveness and distraction will also be measured in the post-lecture survey, where one of the items is a likert scale of 0-10; 0 indicates not being attentive at all, and 10 indicates being extremely attentive:
“ How attentive to the lecture video were you”?
“How distracted were you by the other participants in the room?”
3) Participants will be video recorded, and attentiveness/inattentiveness will be rated based on the (1) amount of time spent looking at the lecture video and (2) the quality of their posture. 
4) A 20 item multiple choice quiz will be given to participants after the lecture video has finished in order to test retention of the material. This will measure the effect of attention on learning through academic performance.
5) The quantity of notes.
6) Social appraisal theory and goal contagion theory will be measured by the following two items on the post-lecture survey respectively:
i.	How important was the content of the lecture video (0 being not at all important and 10 being extremely important).
ii.	How motivated were you to learn the content (0 being not at all motivated, and 10 being extremely motivated)?
7) Participants will be asked at the end of the experiment whether they are interested in receiving additional information on ancient Pompeii through email, and the proportion of students that answer “yes” or “no” will be measured. This will be relevant to providing insight for social appraisal theory and arguably goal contagion theory.
8) Based on prior research, we predict that there will be a positive association between attentiveness and multiple-choice test performance
9) Based on prior research, we predict that participants’ rates of self-reported attentiveness will decrease over time, and that there will be a significant interaction such that participants’ attentiveness will decrease at a faster rate when they are seated with inattentive (vs. attentive confederates).
10) There will be a suspicion-check at the end of the experiment that will ask participants to indicate (in an open-ended response) whether they thought any details of the study were hidden from them by the researchers and, if so, to describe those details.  This question is designed to reveal to us any participants who were suspicious of the confederates during the study.

--Multi-level modeling (with a significance criterion of alpha < .05) will be conducted to compare attentiveness ratings, note-taking, and multiple-choice test performance between conditions and to test for positive associations between these measures.
--distraction ratings will be included as a covariate in the above analyses in which attentiveness, test performance, and note-taking are dependent variables.  That is, we will test whether these effects (which we predict will be statistically significant) will endure when distraction is controlled.
--Pearson correlation coefficients will be reported to test the prediction of a positive correlation between self-reported attentiveness and test performance.
--A Chi-square test will determine whether participants in the attentive-confederate condition (vs. the inattentive-confederate condition) were more likely to request receiving additional information on human vision.
--We will use Process in SPSS to test the hypothesis that notetaking mediates the relation between experimental condition and multiple-choice quiz performance, and also that attentiveness ratings mediate the relation between experimental condition and multiple-choice quiz performance.

q22.value:
--We will conduct two analyses: one with outliers included, and one with outliers excluded. Data that are +/- 3 standard deviations from the mean of each measure will be considered to be an outlier.  Our primary analyses will include these outlier participants and secondary analyses will exclude them.  We will note any differences in statistical significance in footnotes.
--Participants who write down that they were suspicious of the confederates (or realized that the confederates were acting) during the experiment (as revealed by our suspicion check) will be excluded from the primary analyses.

q23.value:
Missing data will be left blank.  
We will exclude participants who did not answer more than half of the self-reported attentiveness ratings or more than half of the multiple-choice questions.  We will also exclude participants who leave full pages from the multiple-choice quiz and the Post-lecture Survey blank.

q24.value: --More specific postdictions regarding our “proximity of confederates” and “visibility of confederates” attention contagion hypothesis will be tested with exploratory analyses (e.g., social networking analyses) after we consult with social networking experts.

attributes.title: Variance-covariance Matrices
attributes.description: Variance-covariance matrices used to generate the models.

q1.value: Analyzing the role of Painful and Provocative Events on the Acquired Capability for Suicide and Impulsivity

q3.value: Though there is evidence that painful and provocative events (PPEs) are associated with suicidal thoughts and behaviours (STBs; Bender, Gordon, Bresin, & Joiner, 2011), the painful and provocative events scale (PPES) has reported poor psychometric properties (Brown et al., 2018). Therefore, the purpose of this study is to analyze the PPES with a formative measurement model. This will test the content and convergent validity of the PPES and provide insight on what variables PPEs are associated with.

q4.value:

question.value:
This is a cross-sectional study design that will use a Fixed-Weight Redundancy Model (FWRM) approach (Chiu, Hsu, Lowry, & Liang, 2018). In this approach, there are two steps: 1) Estimating the weights of the formative indicators using a redundancy analysis model. 2) Fixing the weights obtained from step 1 for the formative indicators and estimating a structural model.

Step 1:
The first redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to a global and reflective measure of the construct (i.e., acquired capability). 

The second redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will also load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to two latent variables that are reflective measures of sensation seeking and negative urgency. 

Step 2:
The weights obtained from step 1 will be used to estimate two structural models. These structural models will test whether acquired capability predicts suicidal intent, NSSI, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours.

question.value: Subjects were collected from a National Guard base in Hattiesburg, Mississipi. Participants were elligible if they were ever enrolled in the U.S. military. They could be at the military base doing drills or returning home from deployment.

q13.value: The dataset contains 953 participants that were enrolled in the U.S. military at the time of data collection. After excluding participants (see exclusion criteria), we will use the all of the remaining data.

question.value:
The formative indicators that will form/define the composite variable are items from the Painful and Provocative Event Scale (PPES). The 25-item version was used. The PPES asked participants, "Please answer the following questions for any time in the past," where participants answered how many times they had experienced several events (e.g., "Have you gone skydiving?"). The PPES contains a scale from 1-5, 1 being "Never" and 5 being "More than 20 times." 

The first redundancy analysis model contains two outcome variables:
1. Perceived pain tolerance. This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. Participants were asked, "Please read each item below and indicate to what extent you feel the statement describes you,' where participants responded on a Likert-type scale from 0 being "Not at all like me" to 4 being "Very much like me." One item from the ACSS will represent pain tolerance: 4 ("I can tolerate more pain than most people"). The description of each item can be found in the attached document of the ACSS.

2. Fearlessness About Death (FAD). This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. The following items from the ACSS will represent FAD: 7 (“The fact that I am going to die does not affect me”), 8 ("The pain involved in dying does not frighten me"; reverse scored), 10 (“I am very much afraid to die”), 11 (“It does not make me nervous when people talk about death”), 13 (“The prospect of my own death arouses anxiety in me”; reverse-scored), 14 (“I am not disturbed by death being the end of life as I know it”), and 19 (“I am not at all afraid to die”). This is consistent with Ribeiro et al's (2014) findings that these 7 items formed a replicable factor structure that is substantively related to fearlessness about death.

The second model contains two outcome variables:
1. Sensation seeking. This refers to one's tendency to seek out thrilling experiences. The was measured with the Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-P). Participants were asked, "Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think. For each statement, please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the statement." Participants responded on a Likert-type scale, with 1 being "Agree strongly" to 4 being "Disagree strongly." The sensation seeking subscale will be used.

2. Negative urgency. This refers to one's tendency to act rashly in the face of negative emotions. The same instructions that were used to measure this variable as they were for sensation seeking. The negative urgency subscale will be used.

question.value:
Sum scores will be used to represent Fearlessness About Death in the redundancy analysis model, with the exception of perceived pain tolerance, which only contains one item.

Scores for each individual item on the sensation seeking and negative urgency subscale will be used to identify the sensation seeking and negative urgency constructs in the second rendundancy analysis model.

Hypothesis #1 (Model 1): We will use a redundancy analysis model to analyze our results. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to a reflective measure of acquired capability (i.e., the ACSS-FAD subscale and pain tolerance as measured by the ACSS). 

Hypothesis #2 (Model 2): A second redundancy analysis model will be fitted to the data. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to latent variables that predict item scores on the negative urgency subscale and the sensation seeking subscale in the UPPS-P. 

Both models will use covariance-based structural equation modelling (CB-SEM) with maximum likelihood estimation.

Following Chiu et al's (2018) procedure. We will use the following criteria to redesign the PPES so only the most relevant items to the formative construct are included:
- Items will be considered for deletion if their path coefficient is too low (ideally, PC > .8)
- Items will be considered for deletion if there's a multicolinearity problem. If the variance inflation factor is greater than 3.3 then the item may be problematic.
- Weights and bivariate correlations that are statistically nonsignificant will be considered for deletion.

Due to the predominant use of multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models in formative measurement models, these models will be compared to the redundancy analysis models to see if there are any major discrepancies or differences. Several nested models of hypotheses 1 and 2 will be fitted to the data:
Model 3: Hypothesis #1 will also be tested with a MIMIC model that has one latent variable and two reflective indicators (ACSS-FAD subscale scores and pain tolerance scores on the ACSS). A chi-square difference test between model 1 and model 3 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Model 4: Hypothesis #2 will be tested by fitting a model that has two latent variables (one latent variable corresponding to negative urgency and the second corresponding to sensation seeking). A chi-square difference test between model 2 and model 4 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

q21.value:
Good model fit will be determined by the following criteria:

Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA): < .06
Comparative Fit Index (CFI): > .95
Tucker Lewis Index (TLI): > .95
Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR): < .08
Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC): < .08
 
Using Burnham and Anderson's (2003) criteria for interpreting Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) scores:
ΔAIC < 2 -> substantial evidence for the model.
3 > ΔAIC 7 -> less support for the model.
ΔAIC > 10 -> the model is unlikely.
Where ΔAIC is the model with the difference between the best model and each other model in the set.

q23.value:
Listwise deletion will be applied to PPES items with missing data. Listwise deletion will also be applied to the pain tolerance item on the PPES. 
Predictive mean matching (PMM) imputation will be applied to all other scores (i.e., ACSS-FAD and UPPS-P scores).

q24.value:
After estimating the measurement models for the PPES, the weights of the formative indicators obtained from these models will be applied to the structural model estimations. This part will be exploratory, as we aim to explore the relationship among the PPEs, acquired capability, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours. Structural models may be informed by theory (e.g., using the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide to see if perceived burdensomeness, thwarted belongingness, and acquired capability predict suicide intent or suicide attempts). However, other variables such as distress tolerance may also be analyzed in relation to PPES scores. 

It is possible that not all PPEs meaningfully contribute to greater ACS or impulsivity. Consequently, new models will be tested that drop items on the PPES that do not have significant or high correlations with the formative construct. Model fit of these newly developed models will be assessed.

registration_responses.q3: Though there is evidence that painful and provocative events (PPEs) are associated with suicidal thoughts and behaviours (STBs; Bender, Gordon, Bresin, & Joiner, 2011), the painful and provocative events scale (PPES) has reported poor psychometric properties (Brown et al., 2018). Therefore, the purpose of this study is to analyze the PPES with a formative measurement model. This will test the content and convergent validity of the PPES and provide insight on what variables PPEs are associated with.
registration_responses.q4:
If higher exposure to painful and provocative events leads to a higher ACS, then higher PPES scores will be associated with higher scores on fearlessness about death and pain tolerance.

We predict that PPES scores will be higher when negative urgency and sensation seeking scores are higher.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Data are archival and all of it has been collected prior to analyses. The data was collected as a part of a previous project entitled “Identifying Factors Associated with Future Self-Directed Violence Within a Sample of Mississippi National Guard Personnel.” The authors pledge that analysis of the data has not been analyzed prior to registration.
registration_responses.q13: The dataset contains 953 participants that were enrolled in the U.S. military at the time of data collection. After excluding participants (see exclusion criteria), we will use the all of the remaining data.
registration_responses.q14: The full sample after excluding invalid cases will be used to maximize power. After excluding participants, we expect to have around 500 - 700 valid cases.
registration_responses.q21:
Good model fit will be determined by the following criteria:

Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA): < .06
Comparative Fit Index (CFI): > .95
Tucker Lewis Index (TLI): > .95
Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR): < .08
Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC): < .08
 
Using Burnham and Anderson's (2003) criteria for interpreting Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) scores:
ΔAIC < 2 -> substantial evidence for the model.
3 > ΔAIC 7 -> less support for the model.
ΔAIC > 10 -> the model is unlikely.
Where ΔAIC is the model with the difference between the best model and each other model in the set.
registration_responses.q23:
Listwise deletion will be applied to PPES items with missing data. Listwise deletion will also be applied to the pain tolerance item on the PPES. 
Predictive mean matching (PMM) imputation will be applied to all other scores (i.e., ACSS-FAD and UPPS-P scores).
registration_responses.q24:
After estimating the measurement models for the PPES, the weights of the formative indicators obtained from these models will be applied to the structural model estimations. This part will be exploratory, as we aim to explore the relationship among the PPEs, acquired capability, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours. Structural models may be informed by theory (e.g., using the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide to see if perceived burdensomeness, thwarted belongingness, and acquired capability predict suicide intent or suicide attempts). However, other variables such as distress tolerance may also be analyzed in relation to PPES scores. 

It is possible that not all PPEs meaningfully contribute to greater ACS or impulsivity. Consequently, new models will be tested that drop items on the PPES that do not have significant or high correlations with the formative construct. Model fit of these newly developed models will be assessed.

registration_responses.q8.question:
This is a cross-sectional study design that will use a Fixed-Weight Redundancy Model (FWRM) approach (Chiu, Hsu, Lowry, & Liang, 2018). In this approach, there are two steps: 1) Estimating the weights of the formative indicators using a redundancy analysis model. 2) Fixing the weights obtained from step 1 for the formative indicators and estimating a structural model.

Step 1:
The first redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to a global and reflective measure of the construct (i.e., acquired capability). 

The second redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will also load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to two latent variables that are reflective measures of sensation seeking and negative urgency. 

Step 2:
The weights obtained from step 1 will be used to estimate two structural models. These structural models will test whether acquired capability predicts suicidal intent, NSSI, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours.
registration_responses.q12.question: Subjects were collected from a National Guard base in Hattiesburg, Mississipi. Participants were elligible if they were ever enrolled in the U.S. military. They could be at the military base doing drills or returning home from deployment.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The formative indicators that will form/define the composite variable are items from the Painful and Provocative Event Scale (PPES). The 25-item version was used. The PPES asked participants, "Please answer the following questions for any time in the past," where participants answered how many times they had experienced several events (e.g., "Have you gone skydiving?"). The PPES contains a scale from 1-5, 1 being "Never" and 5 being "More than 20 times." 

The first redundancy analysis model contains two outcome variables:
1. Perceived pain tolerance. This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. Participants were asked, "Please read each item below and indicate to what extent you feel the statement describes you,' where participants responded on a Likert-type scale from 0 being "Not at all like me" to 4 being "Very much like me." One item from the ACSS will represent pain tolerance: 4 ("I can tolerate more pain than most people"). The description of each item can be found in the attached document of the ACSS.

2. Fearlessness About Death (FAD). This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. The following items from the ACSS will represent FAD: 7 (“The fact that I am going to die does not affect me”), 8 ("The pain involved in dying does not frighten me"; reverse scored), 10 (“I am very much afraid to die”), 11 (“It does not make me nervous when people talk about death”), 13 (“The prospect of my own death arouses anxiety in me”; reverse-scored), 14 (“I am not disturbed by death being the end of life as I know it”), and 19 (“I am not at all afraid to die”). This is consistent with Ribeiro et al's (2014) findings that these 7 items formed a replicable factor structure that is substantively related to fearlessness about death.

The second model contains two outcome variables:
1. Sensation seeking. This refers to one's tendency to seek out thrilling experiences. The was measured with the Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-P). Participants were asked, "Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think. For each statement, please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the statement." Participants responded on a Likert-type scale, with 1 being "Agree strongly" to 4 being "Disagree strongly." The sensation seeking subscale will be used.

2. Negative urgency. This refers to one's tendency to act rashly in the face of negative emotions. The same instructions that were used to measure this variable as they were for sensation seeking. The negative urgency subscale will be used.

q17.uploader.file_name: ACSS items from Ribeiro et al. (2014).doc

registration_responses.q18.question:
Sum scores will be used to represent Fearlessness About Death in the redundancy analysis model, with the exception of perceived pain tolerance, which only contains one item.

Scores for each individual item on the sensation seeking and negative urgency subscale will be used to identify the sensation seeking and negative urgency constructs in the second rendundancy analysis model.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis #1 (Model 1): We will use a redundancy analysis model to analyze our results. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to a reflective measure of acquired capability (i.e., the ACSS-FAD subscale and pain tolerance as measured by the ACSS). 

Hypothesis #2 (Model 2): A second redundancy analysis model will be fitted to the data. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to latent variables that predict item scores on the negative urgency subscale and the sensation seeking subscale in the UPPS-P. 

Both models will use covariance-based structural equation modelling (CB-SEM) with maximum likelihood estimation.

Following Chiu et al's (2018) procedure. We will use the following criteria to redesign the PPES so only the most relevant items to the formative construct are included:
- Items will be considered for deletion if their path coefficient is too low (ideally, PC > .8)
- Items will be considered for deletion if there's a multicolinearity problem. If the variance inflation factor is greater than 3.3 then the item may be problematic.
- Weights and bivariate correlations that are statistically nonsignificant will be considered for deletion.

Due to the predominant use of multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models in formative measurement models, these models will be compared to the redundancy analysis models to see if there are any major discrepancies or differences. Several nested models of hypotheses 1 and 2 will be fitted to the data:
Model 3: Hypothesis #1 will also be tested with a MIMIC model that has one latent variable and two reflective indicators (ACSS-FAD subscale scores and pain tolerance scores on the ACSS). A chi-square difference test between model 1 and model 3 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Model 4: Hypothesis #2 will be tested by fitting a model that has two latent variables (one latent variable corresponding to negative urgency and the second corresponding to sensation seeking). A chi-square difference test between model 2 and model 4 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Due to the predominant use of multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models in formative measurement models, these models will be compared to the redundancy analysis models to see if there are any major discrepancies or differences. Several nested models of hypotheses 1 and 2 will be fitted to the data:
Model 3: Hypothesis #1 will also be tested with a MIMIC model that has one latent variable and two reflective indicators (ACSS-FAD subscale scores and pain tolerance scores on the ACSS). A chi-square difference test between model 1 and model 3 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Model 4: Hypothesis #2 will be tested by fitting a model that has two latent variables (one latent variable corresponding to negative urgency and the second corresponding to sensation seeking). A chi-square difference test between model 2 and model 4 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

attributes.description: All measurements used for the project.

q1.value: Analyzing the role of Painful and Provocative Events on the Acquired Capability for Suicide and Impulsivity

q3.value: Though there is evidence that painful and provocative events (PPEs) are associated with suicidal thoughts and behaviours (STBs; Bender, Gordon, Bresin, & Joiner, 2011), the painful and provocative events scale (PPES) has reported poor psychometric properties (Brown et al., 2018). Therefore, the purpose of this study is to analyze the PPES with a formative measurement model. This will test the content and convergent validity of the PPES and provide insight on what variables PPEs are associated with.

q4.value:
If higher exposure to painful and provocative events leads to a higher ACS, then higher PPES scores will be associated with higher scores on fearlessness about death and pain tolerance.

We predict that PPES scores will be higher when negative urgency and sensation seeking scores are higher.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a cross-sectional study design that will use a Fixed-Weight Redundancy Model (FWRM) approach (Chiu, Hsu, Lowry, & Liang, 2018). In this approach, there are two steps: 1) Estimating the weights of the formative indicators using a redundancy analysis model. 2) Fixing the weights obtained from step 1 for the formative indicators and estimating a structural model.

Step 1:
The first redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to a global and reflective measure of the construct (i.e., acquired capability). 

The second redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will also load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to two latent variables that are reflective measures of sensation seeking and negative urgency. 

Step 2:
The weights obtained from step 1 will be used to estimate two structural models. These structural models will test whether acquired capability predicts suicidal intent, NSSI, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data are archival and all of it has been collected prior to analyses. The data was collected as a part of a previous project entitled “Identifying Factors Associated with Future Self-Directed Violence Within a Sample of Mississippi National Guard Personnel.” The authors pledge that analysis of the data has not been analyzed prior to registration.

question.value: Subjects were collected from a National Guard base in Hattiesburg, Mississipi. Participants were elligible if they were ever enrolled in the U.S. military. They could be at the military base doing drills or returning home from deployment.

q13.value: The dataset contains 953 participants that were enrolled in the U.S. military at the time of data collection. After excluding participants (see exclusion criteria), we will use the all of the remaining data.

q14.value: The full sample after excluding invalid cases will be used to maximize power. After excluding participants, we expect to have around 500 - 700 valid cases.

question.value:
The formative indicators that will form/define the composite variable are items from the Painful and Provocative Event Scale (PPES). The 25-item version was used. The PPES asked participants, "Please answer the following questions for any time in the past," where participants answered how many times they had experienced several events (e.g., "Have you gone skydiving?"). The PPES contains a scale from 1-5, 1 being "Never" and 5 being "More than 20 times." 

The first redundancy analysis model contains two outcome variables:
1. Perceived pain tolerance. This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. Participants were asked, "Please read each item below and indicate to what extent you feel the statement describes you,' where participants responded on a Likert-type scale from 0 being "Not at all like me" to 4 being "Very much like me." One item from the ACSS will represent pain tolerance: 4 ("I can tolerate more pain than most people"). The description of each item can be found in the attached document of the ACSS.

2. Fearlessness About Death (FAD). This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. The following items from the ACSS will represent FAD: 7 (“The fact that I am going to die does not affect me”), 8 ("The pain involved in dying does not frighten me"; reverse scored), 10 (“I am very much afraid to die”), 11 (“It does not make me nervous when people talk about death”), 13 (“The prospect of my own death arouses anxiety in me”; reverse-scored), 14 (“I am not disturbed by death being the end of life as I know it”), and 19 (“I am not at all afraid to die”). This is consistent with Ribeiro et al's (2014) findings that these 7 items formed a replicable factor structure that is substantively related to fearlessness about death.

The second model contains two outcome variables:
1. Sensation seeking. This refers to one's tendency to seek out thrilling experiences. The was measured with the Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-P). Participants were asked, "Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think. For each statement, please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the statement." Participants responded on a Likert-type scale, with 1 being "Agree strongly" to 4 being "Disagree strongly." The sensation seeking subscale will be used.

2. Negative urgency. This refers to one's tendency to act rashly in the face of negative emotions. The same instructions that were used to measure this variable as they were for sensation seeking. The negative urgency subscale will be used.

question.value:
Sum scores will be used to represent Fearlessness About Death in the redundancy analysis model, with the exception of perceived pain tolerance, which only contains one item.

Scores for each individual item on the sensation seeking and negative urgency subscale will be used to identify the sensation seeking and negative urgency constructs in the second rendundancy analysis model.

Hypothesis #1 (Model 1): We will use a redundancy analysis model to analyze our results. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to a reflective measure of acquired capability (i.e., the ACSS-FAD subscale and pain tolerance as measured by the ACSS). 

Hypothesis #2 (Model 2): A second redundancy analysis model will be fitted to the data. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to latent variables that predict item scores on the negative urgency subscale and the sensation seeking subscale in the UPPS-P. 

Both models will use covariance-based structural equation modelling (CB-SEM) with maximum likelihood estimation.

Following Chiu et al's (2018) procedure. We will use the following criteria to redesign the PPES so only the most relevant items to the formative construct are included:
- Items will be considered for deletion if their path coefficient is too low (ideally, PC > .8)
- Items will be considered for deletion if there's a multicolinearity problem. If the variance inflation factor is greater than 3.3 then the item may be problematic.
- Weights and bivariate correlations that are statistically nonsignificant will be considered for deletion.

Due to the predominant use of multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models in formative measurement models, these models will be compared to the redundancy analysis models to see if there are any major discrepancies or differences. Several nested models of hypotheses 1 and 2 will be fitted to the data:
Model 3: Hypothesis #1 will also be tested with a MIMIC model that has one latent variable and two reflective indicators (ACSS-FAD subscale scores and pain tolerance scores on the ACSS). A chi-square difference test between model 1 and model 3 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Model 4: Hypothesis #2 will be tested by fitting a model that has two latent variables (one latent variable corresponding to negative urgency and the second corresponding to sensation seeking). A chi-square difference test between model 2 and model 4 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

q21.value:
Good model fit will be determined by the following criteria:

Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA): < .06
Comparative Fit Index (CFI): > .95
Tucker Lewis Index (TLI): > .95
Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR): < .08
Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC): < .08
 
Using Burnham and Anderson's (2003) criteria for interpreting Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) scores:
ΔAIC < 2 -> substantial evidence for the model.
3 > ΔAIC 7 -> less support for the model.
ΔAIC > 10 -> the model is unlikely.
Where ΔAIC is the model with the difference between the best model and each other model in the set.

q23.value:
Listwise deletion will be applied to PPES items with missing data. Listwise deletion will also be applied to the pain tolerance item on the PPES. 
Predictive mean matching (PMM) imputation will be applied to all other scores (i.e., ACSS-FAD and UPPS-P scores).

q24.value:
After estimating the measurement models for the PPES, the weights of the formative indicators obtained from these models will be applied to the structural model estimations. This part will be exploratory, as we aim to explore the relationship among the PPEs, acquired capability, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours. Structural models may be informed by theory (e.g., using the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide to see if perceived burdensomeness, thwarted belongingness, and acquired capability predict suicide intent or suicide attempts). However, other variables such as distress tolerance may also be analyzed in relation to PPES scores. 

It is possible that not all PPEs meaningfully contribute to greater ACS or impulsivity. Consequently, new models will be tested that drop items on the PPES that do not have significant or high correlations with the formative construct. Model fit of these newly developed models will be assessed.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Lay estimations of public opinion change

analyses.value: Each item will be tested with a two-tailed one-sample t-test. The mu value for each t-test will be the actual amount of change observed in empirical data (collected from Gallup, ANES, GSS, etc.). The p-values from these 51 tests will be corrected with the Holm-Bonferroni method.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded only if they fail one or more attention checks.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is estimated change in public opinions. This will be measured by asking participants to estimate the percentage of Americans who answered in a certain way on a public opinion question in two different years. Estimated change = estimate for later year - estimate for earlier year.

conditions.value: All participants will be assigned to the same condition. Participants will complete a semi-random subset of 20 items out of 51 possible items. The sample is semi-random because eight of the items require extra instructions, so participants will either get the whole block of those eight or none.

hypothesis.value: Do people know how public opinion has changed over time?

attributes.title: Differences in Sustainable Attitudes and Behaviors by Income

q1.value: Differences in Sustainable Attitudes and Behaviors by Income

q2.value: Jenna F. Tipaldo, Mindy Engle-Friedman, Rosina Tenantitla

q3.value: Climate change is a pressing global issue that may pose the greatest threat to those who are already the most vulnerable of society. Do people of different socioeconomic backgrounds differ from one another in their knowledge, thoughts, and feelings towards climate change, its potential impacts, and resiliency? If so or if not, this information could inform efforts to spark action, such as education campaigns or allocation of resources, in those most capable of making change and to help prepare those who might suffer most due to a problem that they did not create.

q4.value:
We predict that Baruch students who have a lower or higher family income level will show no significant differences from one another in their awareness of local environmental threats and vulnerabilities caused by a changing climate. 
We predict that regardless of income level, women will report significantly higher levels of concern for climate change and related issues than men. 
We predict that people with low incomes will report significantly higher levels of fear and lower levels of hope than people with high incomes.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a between-subjects design. Demographic factors like income and gender will sort the subjects, who completed a computer-based survey, into groups for comparison. The data for this study was collected over multiple semesters, although each participant only completed the survey once and hence may be considered a cross-sectional design.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data has been collected using the Sustainable Attitudes and Behaviors questionnaire (Engle-Friedman, 2009) over consecutive semesters. The data from prior to Spring 2019 has been accessed and analyzed, but never has income been used to split the data into groups for comparison. Men and women were compared in previous analyses prior to Spring 2019 collection. Income has also been examined with regard to basic demographics.

question.value: Data was collected from a participant pool of undergraduate students in introductory psychology and introductory management classes at Baruch College, City University of New York, a public university in New York City with both liberal arts and business schools.

q13.value: We are collecting data from at least 50 people per semester, up to as many participants as we can survey.

question.value: The Sustainable Attitudes and Behaviors questionnaire includes questions about the perceived importance of sustainable behaviors, the frequency of sustainable behaviors, awareness of environmental issues, and sustainable attitudes, including questions about concern, hope, fear, and attribution of responsibility about climate change. The survey also includes the New Ecological Paradigm and the Connectedness to Nature Scale. The survey collects demographic information such as age, gender, income, ethnicity, nationality, and major of study.

The measures of perceived importance of sustainable behaviors, frequency of sustainable behaviors, awareness of environmental issues, sustainable attitudes, Connectedness to Nature, and New Ecological Paradigm. Scores for each measure will be calculated for comparison between income groups.

This data will be analyzed using between subject comparisons in which gender, income and income satisfaction will be used to identify separate groupings. Those groups will be compared on perceived importance of sustainable behaviors, frequency of sustainable behaviors, awareness of environmental issues, sustainable attitudes, Connectedness to Nature, and New Ecological Paradigm. Additional analyses will look for interactions between gender and income.

q22.value: Participants were asked to indicate their comfort reading, writing, speaking and understanding English on three 4-point scales (1=Not at all comfortable; 5 = Extremely comfortable) Those who indicated 2 or less will be excluded from the data analyses. Participants who did not complete the survey or who choose the same answer throughout the survey (e.g. answered with only choice 4) were excluded.

q23.value: Those who do not provide demographic information will be excluded from data analyses. Since the computer program prevented participants from moving forward when the didn’t answer a question, we have very few participants without a fully-completed data set.

The survey also includes the New Ecological Paradigm and the Connectedness to Nature Scale. The survey collects demographic information such as age, gender, income, ethnicity, nationality, and major of study.
registration_responses.q18.question: The measures of perceived importance of sustainable behaviors, frequency of sustainable behaviors, awareness of environmental issues, sustainable attitudes, Connectedness to Nature, and New Ecological Paradigm. Scores for each measure will be calculated for comparison between income groups.
registration_responses.q19.question: This data will be analyzed using between subject comparisons in which gender, income and income satisfaction will be used to identify separate groupings. Those groups will be compared on perceived importance of sustainable behaviors, frequency of sustainable behaviors, awareness of environmental issues, sustainable attitudes, Connectedness to Nature, and New Ecological Paradigm. Additional analyses will look for interactions between gender and income.
